Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2011 10:14PM JeanH wrote: Hi ladies, I had treatment #7 of 30 today....first full week for me too very tired but think that is from working too many hours and not sleeping enough....1:10am should be sleeping now in fact. Skin holding up am using a steroid cream in the morning as a preventative and eurcerin at night. Found soft cup bra but not sure how comfortable it will be as things progress. I agree the driving back and forth is probably a big part of the fatigue. But the staff is wonderful and I am getting into the routine..... Nice to meet all of you. Jean
Posts.Title: JUNE 2011 RADS bluewillowskys duckyb1

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 05:25PM JeanH wrote: Vis0121, So sorry you are feeling so bad today, I hope you see some improvement soon or they find some other med to help relieve the SE. Proudmom, UtahMom and Julie, Thanks for all the lists. and Utahmom the articles on soy too.  It is a confusing issue so additional information helps. Jean

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2011 07:34PM JeanH wrote: Hang in there ladies we are there for you. Vis, hope you keep improving and next round is better. Amy glad to here you may be able to remove the pump, we will keep our fingers crossed for you. wishing you all a good day tomorrow, or at least a better one. Hugs to all. I am getting more and more nervous as things move closer. Suddenly 2/3 seems very close at hand. Jean
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2011 11:25AM JeanH wrote: Amara so sorry you are joining our club. This is an excellent resource, I also found having a very current reference book to read was helpful, I am the type that needs to know. I use the 5th edition of dr. Susan love's The Breast Book, which has very good sections on explaining what your pathology reports mean and the various treatment options. Reading through this thread from the beginning will give you lots of wonderful information from wonderful women in various stages of Chemo for various types of cancer. There are other very useful threads in the chemotherapy forum that I found to be very helpful, tips for getting through chemo and more tips for getting through chemo were very useful with lots of practical information. Most of all make sure your doctors make everything clear so you are comfortable. I am starting DD EC then DD T on feb 3. My doctors go with chemo whenever the cancer gets to the lymph nodes if possible. The words they keep saying is you are young and otherwise healthy so we are going to go after this with every thing they've got to give me the best shot of no spread as possible. Sisters I hope you are all feeling better, even good today. UTAHMOM glad you are home again. ALIT your photo is beautiful. I have to upload one still. Becky, I hope your were able to enjoy the craft fair. I agree we all need large medicine cabinets, the list of meds we need is a bit overwhelming but if it helps us defeat this they we do what we need to do. It really hit home how close Feb 3 is yesterday when my Neulasta shot delivery was confirmed for next week. It seems the claritan is helping many of you, can you confirm that you start the day before injections and continue for 3 days?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 08:15PM JeanH wrote: Hi all, Welcome to our new members, my heart goes out to you. Just wanted to send out good thoughts so many wonderful posts these last 2 days with great advice. Seems like a lot of us are such doers and really have to work at the resting and asking for help. I loved the book 5 things I didn't learn from cancer, it made me laugh when I really needed it. I also type on an iPad and have some strange substitutions made. I don't alway catch them and sometimes you cannot get to the right place again to fix. I had my MUGA test today to make sure my heart is ready for the EC....very tired and snow has ramped up yet again. School is delayed, work still on. Hope everyone starts to or continues to feel better. Jean

Thanks for being my guideposts and ladies whomhave gone before and for all the wonderful support. It has helped knowing what to expect. I am doing ok after round one, went to work today for most of the day..... Jean

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2011 07:52PM JeanH wrote: glad to hear everyone is hanging in. for those who had the big fatigue after the decatron, my doctor recommends splitting the last days dose of 3 pils to 2 one day and 1 the following day, feels it helps avoid the full crash. worth asking about if you went through it on the earlier cycles. did any of you get asore throat after Chemo? I am using biotin but still sore? Jean

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2011 08:47PM JeanH wrote: Oh and I can actually see eyelashes and hair again very very short but absolutely visible! Jean
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2011 07:55PM JeanH wrote: Wow what  busy day everyone has had! Mary Margaret when I read your post this morning I couldn't believe all you did in one day never mind before dinner!  Please pace yourself - I get the push and get things done mentality but as everyone is saying we have a long road ahead of us and want to keep up our energy to continue our battles.  None of us should feel guilty about not getting everything done (please play that back to me in a few weeks once I am hopefully underway,)  I have been thinking about you all day and finally can see you have rested some more.  So glad your solo went well. that must have felt amazing for you. I'll bet your son was proud of that beef stroganoff....My son who actually likes to cook and test new recipes is off at college so that is not going to help. DH does cook but not vegetables and not what I would call comfort food -makesa great roast chicken and killer cookies though so I am not going to complain. Welcome to all our new January chemo sisters, sorry you are in the club. Aimee, Jane,Suz3, AmyMac, tideknott, webu, starella. Hope I did not miss anyone. Congratulations IslandMom on your son's confirmation, so glad you were able to be there for it.  I don't think water bottles look odd at all :)  I hope the pains stay away today. UTMom, your walk and exercise informaton was inspirational - it's tough to walk outside with the snow ( and more is coming tomorrow) but may have to do the treadmill or bike now that I can breathe again. Hope you are feeling better, we'll hope you have low se too. Get some rest and take care of yourself.  Thanks for the reference articles on exercise I admit I have been off schedule since the diagnosis,  I started back with my Pilates class a couple of weeks ago,  now need to get more in around the work day. These articles will be additional incentive to do so. At 52 the doctors keeps saying I am young and healthy (except for the BC thing) so we are going to hit it with everything to keep it that way. Exercise can only help right. Suz3. I haven't done the wig thing yet - I guess I am waiting to hear what the chemo is.  I am starting to think I should be looking and the process may not be as simple as go to a shop and get one...I did cut my hair shorter with bangs and buy some scarves and wraps.  The look good feel better class sound fun. JulieH &vis0121 thanks for the info on grades - I went back to by pathology reports they do not state grade and in fact the surgery one is quite sketchy I think I have a preliminary report and get the full details when I meet the ONC Monday.  The initial one from the biopsy does not have grade listed but it does have the components that make up the grade and the individual scores so with that and Susan Love's The Breast Book as translator it looks like I fall in the grade 2 range.  A friend who went through this last year at MSK said the ONC visit was where they really laid it out. Julie - I have to keep checking where you are from - your descriptions sound like the cold Northeast not SC. stay warm.  Jane - I should know what my dates and regimen are on Monday.  I hope you don't have to join us but we are here if you need us.  There does not appear to be a question of whether or not I need it - ILC and 2 positive nodes seem to make it a foregone conclusion. Just when and what. ProudMom_Wife. Glad you are feeling better. our DHs and children are unsung heroes. Kym61 - hope the wig shopping was successful. tideknot/Beckie,  Welcome, My DH and I just celebrated our 30th last week last week. Congratulations.  We are still deciding on how to celebrate when this is done and Ireland is at the top of the list. We went 2 summers ago.  The first time for DH and my sons and we (DH) drove around the coast, from Belfast to Dublin, it was so beautiful, even in the rain. DH is still recovering from the roads in the west but said he will go back to Dublin again :). My parents are both from Dublin so it is always special to visit. Let's hope BC cooperates. June is a great time to go. Long long evenings and usually decent weather.  Warriorprincess24 - glad first day was uneventful. lets hope all are the same. Ipod definitely going in the Chemo bag with iPad. Definitely a techie at heart  -only problem is you cannot post from the iPad need to get back to a computer to do that (fix supposedly in the works.) Webu, I agree hearing the stories and having the ability to compare notes definitely helps us prepare... Hope all goes well tomorrow for all of you, high energy low se and lots of love and kindnesses. Jean
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2011 08:56PM - edited Jan 11, 2011 08:58PM by JeanH Julie, I have read that hormone positve women should avoid soy but I have seen conflicting info. I stopped eating/drinking it for now.  Good night ladies, apparently I cannot spell/type tonight...  I wish you all a good day tomorrow. Jean
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 06:40PM JeanH wrote: Hi Ladies, Been  reading the posts on my phone and following along and thinking of all of you even when I could not post back. I can totally relate to all the job discussions.  I don't even know what I am getting yet or when, first ONC visit is Monday due to holiday and his vacation, but am stressing already about being able to do everything, I have a demanding schedule with a lot on the calendar for this year, everyone is being extremely supportive but I am stressed trying to get everything in order before I start.  I hope to work through treatment - what ever it is.  I am realistic, I know it will not be at full speed and maybe that's why the rush now before it starts.  I thought the advice to step back and concentrate on our treatment was excellent now just have to get the rest of me on board with it.  I am hoping once I have a concrete treatment plan and not so many unknowns it will help.  I know work will be a distraction, I do like what I do and who I work with, I have an excellent team and they are all loving and supportive. I have been there for over 25 years.  I think the fact I had such a long wait between the surgery  on December 1 and  my first oncologist visit is not helping...sorry ladies I know you are all dealing with so much.  I love that we are all supporting each other, that we are sharing our concerns, tips and victories not matter how big or small.  On the other hand I think I will have no trouble taking it easy with housework :). never that great at it in the first place.  I want my energy to go to battling the beast and family. Weird in theory the cancer is out of me but it did make it to the lymph nodes so the battle continues. Thanks for "listening".  wish all of you the best.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2011 09:21PM JeanH wrote: City kitty, they fixed the typing on iPhone iPad problem it now works. Some glitches and weird word switches but workable. Ckmomo I can't imagine having the push cars they hike through snow after surgery, I think you got your exercise in for the week. It seems like the schools all have the 5:00-6:00 time slot for snow closing delay notification. Ours does the same and calls every number on file, home, my cell, Dh cell and my office...occasionally they make the call the night before but not often. Work sends the text in the same time slot and then I have to get up and change the away message on the office phone, a pet peeve of the CEO if they are not updated to reflect our status, and he does check.... Wig shopping tomorrow, did not confirm appointment until yesterday so going on my own. Neulasta shots arrived yesterday ready to go, my chemo teach is right before my first Chemo. Hope my brain takes it in. Good luck to all, Jean
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 08:57PM JeanH wrote: Mary Meg Getting the Happy Birthday in just under the wire! Hope the LGFB program was fun, I think the soonest I can get in march. Webu so glad things are working better with your daughter. My DS is also 19 and we dad a different kind of tough ride with him but being away at college has been good for all of us...much less stress. He is such a great kid but high anxiety in high school = high stress levels at home. He is learning to loosen up, still maintaining high standards for him self but more accepting of himself and more relaxed. He had a built in tiger Mom that I needed to take the edge off.... On the positive list, the love and support I get from my family and friends and work family. Hugs upon request from both DS. If you have older sons you know this is big! The love and support and positive outlook from my usually negative about the outside world husband. A new ability to put things in pspective, working on relaxing, eating better and exercising more...more incentive to do all three. On a lighter note trying out new hair styles, lower maintenance hair. Not I really need to try sleep. 1 chemo down 7 to go....so far mild headache and major aversion to wronged food smells only SE. Not too bad...hoping to continue in a similar manner through weekend and maybe a part day at work Monday. Maybe dreaming but we will see. Tomorrow either DH or I doing the Neulasta injection. More fun. Night all, thanks for all the support. jean
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 09:05PM JeanH wrote: Sherry I agree you need to find a way to tell your daughter,, maybe the letter will work for you too. You don't want to hav e that as an added layer of separation between you. You don't have to take nasty but I think you should try. It might even turn out positive. I understand why you haven't, I stopped telling friend a one point because they were so upset.I had to ask one friend to tell others in the group so they would not be crying when. They called me is there someone else that can be a bridge that she trusts and respects and you do too that can tell her or read the letter on your behalf so she has processing time and you are shielded if needed? Jean

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 07:43PM JeanH wrote: Hi Ladies, Thanks for the constipation tips I I have been going back and forth and trying to find a balance. Regarding steroids I have 3 decatrons for the day after and the next and then the doctor has me split the dose to2 then 1 to avoid the crash... I don't have the steroid rush, or sleeplessness, have always been a night owl. Hair is seriously shedding now, very thin in spots wore a scarf to leave house today, wig not in until wednesday, so much for ordering early. If anyone is having problems with dry nose my nurse recommend AYR saline gel and it has helped a lot and does not smell. {{{HUGS}}}} Jean
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: May 5, 2011 05:53PM JeanH wrote: Hi ladies, Those suffering through AC or EC #3 - it was definitely my worst in the entire cycle #4 ended up being much better so hang in there. I have an breast MRI scheduled for after Chemo the first of my followups, 6 mos later a mammogram. My simulation for rads was scheduled for may 31' the rehearsal is June 8 and rads start on June 9. I am scheduled for 25 with 5 boosts so 6weeks. I tried pushing out another week but he really did not want me to unless it was an emergency....I figure a business trip that I have been putting off doesn't count so moving forward... Did I tell younhow much I am dreading the daily drive...ok ti e to get over it and just move forward the sooner it starts the sooner it finishes. Sounds like we will have to get a June rads board started for the january alumnae. Happy mothers day to all the moms in our group. Jean
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: May 5, 2011 08:45PM JeanH wrote: Christine, I have one more Chemo next Thursday then it is time for the happy dance that this phase of treatment is over. I alway feel so comfortable with th e January ladies so I will continue to pop in. I have to remind myself I am making the choice to drive the distance to rads to stay in the Sloan network as I am so comfortable with the doctors. It would be easier to go to a local hospital but I trust my Sloan team and decide to stay. We have already proved we can handle what we need to and it is only 6 weeks. Plus you are right a chance to put the top down and enjoy the Sumer weather :) Jean

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2011 10:33PM JeanH wrote: Hi ladies, Is everyone done with Chemo now? I am finished Rads as well and just taking tamoxifin. The hot flashes are annoying but bearable. I have eyelashes eyebrows and hair completely covers my scalp so I am going with the ultra short pixiie look....the wig was too hot and the hot flashes seem to always create a very hot head. My energy levels are back to normal(most of the time.). I am feeling like me again. I actually think I am going to keep my hair short for a while, but not quite this short (barely 1/2 inch.) Thanks to all of you for all the support you are all amazing, Love, Jean
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2011 12:05PM JeanH wrote: Thank you for all the welcomes and the timeline guidance.  I moved so fast from finding the lump to diagnosis, MRI anad Pet scan then to surgery, now back in wait mode for the ONC appointment.  I feel like everything is on hold until I know what the treaatment will be and how it will affect me. I am making appointments setting up meeting not knowing if i can actually attend. Work is very supportive i think I just have to roll with it...not the easiest thing. sltst12> I think your friend gave us all great advice, thanks for sharing. The more in control we feel in this situation the better our outlook.  When my Dad was sick my Mom would have hard times getting the informaation she needed from doctors.  She worked at the time and had no problem getting what she needed there. I reminded her the doctors are there to help us, they are providing service to us. If she started to think of them as a vendor it would help...she said it worked.  I have been lucky with a great medical team but we have to be proactive too, keeping our lists of questions and asking them until we understand. I am building that list for my first ONC visit from all your helpful infomation.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 06:00PM JeanH wrote: Moe1279 - So happy to hear confirmation your tumor is shrinking.  I am so happy for you. GOod luck to all starting Chemo and wishing light se to all in process. Jean
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2011 08:52PM JeanH wrote: hi everyone checking in, Moe, I am also dealing with breakouts and periods from hell...I am 52 and had not had one since last July then one end of January and again this week barely 3 weeks later with bad lower back pain. I actually though I was gettin pain from the nuelasta again. nose is also dry and showing blood, will try upping saline and see if that helps. I have the burned tip of tongue thing and could not think of what I burned it on. strange. SCience girl, my brain is definitely in a chemo fog in the morning seems to be more normal in the afternoons.. I have to definitely schedule different work activities for times when my brain works better. on the bright side I have been able to work most days. Now in the prep stage getting everything set for round 2 thursday and the first foggy week. I have been told the hair start to seriously start coming out about day 2 after second DD treatment, Iam on EC. This means this weekend, well I have an extra day to get it cut..wig has not yet arrived but thanks to all of your suggests have the haps and wraps ready if needed. Hang in there good luck to all getting treatment this week. Jean
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2011 09:38PM JeanH wrote: Hi Ladies, Round 2 of EC a bit tougher than round one, needed to break out the comazine this round but it worked like a charm and all nausea and queasiness gone. headache started faster this round and tylenol did not work as well/Mary Meg i needed serious nap certificates this round! Slept yesterday from 5 til 7 the next morning with a few short breaks to check mon family and go to bathroom. I have not had the steroid wonder woman rush...or if I am scared to see what I would be without, It is exciting to see so many ending round 1, glad to hear round 3 not necessarily worse than round 2 and we are all coping fairly well. My head is starting to tingle and small clumps coming out...should have some serious bald spots by Tuesday according to the doctor/hope the wig arrives on time. Someone sent me a chemo comfort kit with a satin pillowcase so may that is helping lessen the night shedding. some serious fog brain here too, especially in the mornings. Sisct -love the pirate card! Julie {{HUGS}} hope you feel better. Nite all. Jean

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2011 09:02PM JeanH wrote: Hi January Girls, congrats to all making it the the end of first Chemo cocktail. My ONc tested for D with my first blood workup and like most north easterners in winter I was low so he put me on a weekly supplement for 8 weeks then every other week. Based on my rx I will continue Nuelasta through Taxol but doctors said the nausa meds will lessen or go away as most do not have nasea issues with taxol. Good night ladies. Jean chemo plan in signature
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2011 08:47PM JeanH wrote: islandMom-Glad first round went well - Hope you continue to feel good throughout the treatment. VIs0121 - Congratulations on getting a start date and that you were able to get Fridays.Good luck with the port and first infusion next Friday, we are sending hugs and caring thoughts your way.  I would keep your hair for your birthday (or the other extreme do something really fun with it.) It seems to be day 14 is when the major losses start so you have another week to go after the birthday. I have read a bit about the cold caps on other threads I think you have to keep them on for 3 hour after treatment but you can travel home with them. Not sure if that will work for girls in the northeast winter...brrrr.  I am leaning towards  the hair grows back side and you have all given such great referrals for gaila, franceluxe, etc that we can  rock the turban/hat/scarf/wig look for a few months. UTMom, Hope you are still doing well and nausea has continued to subside.  Was impressed you came home and went for a walk. That's great. Good luck with the rest of the weekend and workweek.  I am hoping to continue work while going through this but we need to remember to take care of our ourselves and not push it too hard (this is going to be tough for me according to friends and family.)  Proud Mom & Melissa - a friend who went through this last year said days 3-4 were were her worst and then uphill again, hope you both feel better soon. Julie you are amazing at keeping track of all of us. Thank you! I love the idea of doing something fun with each treatment or a countdown - even hoping that infusion day is not too bad and can do chemo dates with girlfriends.. will give DH a break from driving into the city each time.  Everyone wants to help and this would spread out the driving among friends. Still waiting for oncologist appointment and chemo plan, turns out the wait was good as I have a bad cold now, but should be cleared by the time I see the doc. Did you get told your grade by BS? in pathology report? or by oncologist?  I have no notation on grade or stage in either the initial biopsy or the lumpectomy pathology report. I can figure out stage 2B from books and the size of tumor and the lymph node involvement but not grade. Just curious. Thank you for all the love and support from an amazing, strong, funny, group of women. It helps to have a sounding board and information sources. Jean
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2011 08:49PM JeanH wrote: Vis and Amy - I hope you are both starting to feel better. UTMom - hope the WBC goes up soon without incident. I am so inspired by all of the exercise stories...now to act on it.  I am taking a Pilates class weekly but the walking has stoped with all the snow and the cold...I need to get to the gym and it sounds like mornings are the best way to make it work --- I am so not a morning person. The other way I found worked for me was to go straight from work without stopping home, but that seems less likely on Chemo. It seems most of you feel better in the mornings. Saw the ONC today turns out I am a February Chemo girl now. I start Feb 3 on EC DD 4 cycles then T for 4 cycles. This is equivalent of the AC then T schedule many of you are on. Apparently the shortage of A the standard in the USA has led to a substitution of E (epirubicin) in my cancer center and E has been standard in Europe, same class of drug same SE and same results. The Neulasta shot is self injected the day after tx.  MSKCC gives this routinely for all dose dense schedules. Should be interesting as my only experience with giving injections was injecting our late turtle several years ago with antibiotics (OK to to laugh, everyone else did too) , at least I will not wiggle so much ( I hope).  if my hairs follows the schedule I will start losing my hair right after Valentines Day, but thanks to you ladies I will be prepared with my wraps and scarves. Plan to go wig shopping soon now that it is definite, but not sure how I will feel wearing it, I think for work. You are so right it is a very personal decision and we all need to do what feels best for us.  I dropped a lot of RX at the center pharmacy to pick up for the first TX.  Now that I am going over my notes not entirely sure if I am getting emend or not in the IV, definitely have 3 day dose of pills that start Chemo day, steroids and additional antinausea meds for breakthrough issues. Thanks to all of you I went in prepared and educated. My head is still processing all the information. Now need to get some additional tests in prep for the TX  and wait again. Good luck to Julie and all those getting TX tomorrow. Hope the rest of you have a good day, with low or no SE. Hugs to all, Jean
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 04:27PM JeanH wrote: Mary Meg, glad you're back you always have something to make us laugh. Julie and utahMom thanks for the info on the claritan for Neulasta, my nurses suggested injecting in thigh - I get the lesson with the chemo teach immediately before my first TX. It is so good to have the support of this group. It does help. Science girl, I have tingling in my hand but from the SNB incision, told it can take months to go away completely while the nerves heal from the surgery. Amy utahMom And all those who have been able to work out during treatment, you are an inspiration. AmyK thanks for the suggestions on candied Ginger and Ginger tea, adding to the arsenal. ProudMom, I agree we've got to look for those silver linings to keep us going. Less maintenance for the hair is a good one. Julie I hope you knee is feeling better. My Franceluxe wrap arrived and the fabric is and feels beautiful, was expecting it to be fuller but imagine without hair it will be perfect. I need to go wig shopping the week as I think there will be times I will need it. I did the first level cut going with more layers and bangs, after wig shopping I thing I need to go shorter it seems to help, I think it would be a good step on the way to shaving. Are any of you working with nutritionists? I am worried about the joint pain, I already deal with that from an old back injury and the beginnings of arthritis in my knee, at 52 I think I 'm a bit older than many of you.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 09:43PM JeanH wrote: HI ladies, Just checking in, congrats to all who are finished or almost there.  I just completed Taxol #3 one more to go.   I can relate to the rad discussions, have decided to stay with Sloan but at a regional office which is still a 40 minute drive each way,I feel more comfortable there than going to a local hospital and like having all my records in one place.   But my drive is not that terrible to stay with them..may be of a different opinion once I start the daily commute - This will have more of an impact on working than chemo!  The NYC center is actually closer but I cannot count on traffic cooperating and the parking fees will add up going daily. Jean
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: May 12, 2011 09:12PM JeanH wrote: Betsy, I went with Lump, I had clear margins so stayed with it figuring I could do MX in future if needed. If I remember correctly the lump/rads and mX recurrence were pretty close. The reality is that the tomoxofin is what really reduces our recurrence rates since we are ER/PR positive. I basically went with why take out something that does not show signs PDF disease in MRI and scan. With ILC I think there is a higher chance or recurrence in other breast but will take that road only if and when I get there, I am large busted so the only surgery I even thought about was a reduction and at this point I am thinking leave well enough alone. I like that my breasts still have sensation and don't want to risk losing that if not required. Since I went with lUmp no choice on the rads....even decided to go with tattoos to avoid issues with markings wearing off or reactions to adhesive on stickers. My ro felt pretty strongly that Tats are the way to go, seemed to be more important since I need to do lying on my stomach. In the end you have to do what will give you the most piece of mind/best quality of life. It is hard making all these decisions, Jean
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

I have friends working who have young children and they are exhausted it is too hard to pull back on the kids so you need to pull back on work. We all do so some extent. I am so glad not to be doing the college application marathon this year, that was exhausting on it's own. Jean

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2011 01:33PM JeanH wrote: Hi Ladies, I am a newbie and this is my first post. I wanted to thank all of you for all the information contained in this forum.  I hope to be a January 2011 start - the sooner you start the sooner it will be over - right? My lumpectomy was Dec 1 and luckily clean margins, the cancer found cleared the 2mm mark so no additional surgery now. I have 2 involved nodes so Chemo  followed by rads then hormone blockers is the expected plan per the surgeon.  She told me to expect 8 cycles of chemo over 4 months. My first oncologist appointment is 1/17. due to dr. availabilty,  Can anyone tell me did they start treatment pretty soon after their first visit or is there a waiting period for additional testing/evaluation?  The surgeon/oncologist are in the same center so the records and test results are all there and available. I have ILC 2.3 cm. no idea what grade but told not especially aggressive just hard to see in mammograms, by descriptions I read stage is IIb.  I am a working mom but my kids and husband are pretty self sufficient, they are used to me working out of the house all day. Appreciate all this advice and the sounding board. It is good to have a place where you are feel to ask and not feel the need to always "be strong". Currently DH gets the monopoly on that part.... Good luck to you all who are starting their treatments now.  A friend who started in december suggested sucking on ice to help prevent mouth sores and a nurse friend said sour hard candy helps with the metallic taste if you get that. Jean

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 01:29AM JeanH wrote: hi all I have ILC with 2 nodes out of the 5 removed positive, because of the new studie let the other be. The first breast surgeon i saw ordered MRI and PET scan immediately to confirm no spread since my initial biopsyn showed one node involved, they noticed swollen in mammogram and deduced to biopsy with lump. I think the ILC may have influenced that decision sine it is harder to dedect. Both tests came back clear and both surgeons I saw were very comfortable with lumpectomy. second surgeon recommended SNB first wanted to do full discesstion, I went with the second on the basis of not removing more than needed. WIth only 2 nodes involved i fell into the keep the rest category. Hi to my feb chemo sisters, i am on round 2 of 4 rounds of dd ec followed by 4 rounds of dd T. It has not been anywhere near as bad as I feared. The steroids are for anti nausea. I get emend by pill, something in IV (really should look next time and write down, they told me first time but chemo brain has wiped it out of memory :)) i take decatron (steroid) in morning with emend and nurse gives to me just before chemo as well. decatronb dose split last 2 days to avoid the fatigue that can come when it ends. I have not experienced the steroid rush. I am trying to exercise but finding it hard the first week, am hoping to be able to start walking now that the snow it starting to melt. Have been doing Pilates class but so far not first week, just some stretches. After Chemo I will have rads then hormone blockers for at least 5 years due to er+ pr+ status. probably start on tamoxifin since I somehow still test premenopausal... I am drinking lots of water too. especially the 2 days before day of and 2 days after. to keep hydrated and flush out the chemicals. Warm hands help the prink if you don't have a port. I don't have one and those wonderful Chemo nurse got me on first try both times. My center will give you a hand warmer if you haves are cold (from water bottle or just being outside) Check the 2 threads tips for Chemo and more tips and shopping list for Chemo, they have lots of great tips and suggestions for what to have on standby. The ONC and BS said even though technically all the cancer was removed and margins were clear we do the Chemo because we want to make sure no rogue cells excapes and I have the lowest risk of recurrence or mets possible so Here I am doing Chemo and Kicking cancer Butt - my sisters favorite line of encouragement! My doctor also said the sentinel nodes did their job and captured the cancer. but we still do Chemo.... I am also on vitamin D since my counts were low on the original blood test. good luck to all. Jean

Posts.Content: May 22, 2011 12:38AM JeanH wrote: Thanks every one for sharing your journey and all the tips. I was given an rx cream to use and theta recommend ercerin creme alternating and none for 4hours before treatment. Figuring the medicated creme in the morning rads in pm and the moisurizer in the evening. I will be on my stomach as well, combination of large breast,left side and site location I think. I am hoping to use the non wire bra I wore after the lumpectomy but much prefer the underwire support. No way I can go to work without supporti g the girls so I hope the bra is wearable. I am trying for afternoon treatments but had to give a 2hour window. Leaving for a 2:00 appointment everyday is going to be tough I hope it ends up closer to 4. Ok I have to stop stress g about what has not happened yet and see was the schedule is. I guess I will get it at the simulation. I agree we keep getting told that rads are nothing but I thinknthey will impact my life more than Chemo. I this it is the5days a week. The tattoos and vulnerability. I am worried that rads will interfer with working more than Chemo did....and it is probably the whole surgery chemo rads combination that starts getting to us. My simulation is scheduled for the 31 and rads start June 9.

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2011 10:01PM JeanH wrote: Joyce, my bs said the newest studies have shown with a lumpectomy/radiation and less than 3 positive nodes the results were the same for just taking the affected nodes and doing a complete dissection. Since I have 2 positive nodes she said no more surgery, I would want positive enough defined, again my experience was there was one margin with a tiny amout of cancer but since it was over 2mm from the edge it was considered clear. I hope this helps. Jean
